title: 106_hr1966
content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children and school absenteeism. The prevalence of asthma has been increasing, especially among low-income families and women. In low-income families, 79.2 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 have asthma, costing the US over $12 billion annually. African Americans have higher asthma death rates and are more likely to seek emergency care. Exercise can improve the physical and psychological well-being of African American children, helping them manage asthma and develop lifelong habits of physical activity. SEC. 3. Grants for asthma-related activities in low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to public and nonprofit entities for projects in low-income communities, including screenings, education, and workshops on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Screenings and referrals must be comprehensive and provided in various settings like hospitals and clinics. The Secretary ensures comprehensive screenings and referrals for respiratory problems in various settings, including traditional medical settings and nontraditional locations like schools, community centers, and government offices. Information and education on asthma and allergies are provided in appropriate language and cultural context. The information and education provided includes understanding symptoms, preventing, monitoring, and managing conditions like asthma. It emphasizes the importance of physical activities for asthmatic children. Settings for education include traditional and nontraditional locations. The importance of physical activities for asthmatic children is emphasized in education settings, including traditional and nontraditional locations. Evaluations of projects under subsection (a) involve determining the impact on asthma prevention and management, as well as assessing the effectiveness of educational materials. A condition for receiving a grant is that the applicant must be a community-based organization. The grant program requires applicants to be community-based organizations providing services in low-income communities. The Secretary must approve grant applications that meet necessary requirements. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 4. NATIONAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO PROVIDE ASTHMA-RELATED INFORMATION. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, with a focus on children. The campaign must include information on prevention and management of these conditions, as well as resources available in communities for screenings, referrals, and treatment. It should be conducted in the most appropriate language and cultural context for the community. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, with a focus on children. The campaign includes prevention and management information, as well as resources for screenings, referrals, and treatment in appropriate language and cultural context. Authorization of appropriations is set at $600,000 for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 45D. Taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services can receive a donation credit equal to 10% of the costs incurred in providing qualified services. Qualified services include those provided for free in public housing or multifamily residential properties with low-income occupants. Taxpayers can receive a donation credit for providing pest control or climate control services to low-income occupants in public housing or multifamily residential properties. The services must be part of a good faith effort to help those with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line. Taxpayers engaged in providing pest control or climate control services can receive a donation credit under section 45D. Unused credits cannot be carried back before January 1, 2000. Taxpayers can receive a donation credit for providing pest control and climate control services under section 45D. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Additionally, there is research being conducted on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related problems. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA Administrator, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Priority will be given to individuals in low-income communities for clinical evaluations. The paragraph refers to individuals residing in low-income communities with family incomes at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal programs for asthma, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress. A representative from the Department of Housing and Urban Development will be included in the coordinating committee. $5,000,000 will be allocated to the National Asthma Education Prevention Program. Authorization of $5,000,000 from NIH funds for National Asthma Education Prevention Program for fiscal years 2000-2004. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, will conduct local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They will compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma in each state and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each state.
